Question: How can I normalize the EOL character in Java?: :I have a linux server and many clients with many operating systems. The server takes an input file from clients. Linux has end of line char LF, while Mac has end of line char CR, andWindows has end of line char CR+LFThe server needs as end of line char LF. Using java, I want to ensure that the file will always use the linux eol char LF. How can I achieve it?
Please using this api: DataOutputStream.write.
Answer: You can achieve this by reading the file line by line using BufferedReader and then writing each line to the DataOutputStream with a line separator of "\n". Here is an example:

<<<api>>>: BufferedReader, DataOutputStream
<<<code>>>:
```java
BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new FileReader("input.txt"));
DataOutputStream outputStream = new DataOutputStream(new FileOutputStream("output.txt"));

String line;
while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
    outputStream.writeBytes(line + "\n");
}

reader.close();
outputStream.close();
```
<<<explanation>>>: In this code, we first create a BufferedReader to read the input file line by line. We then create a DataOutputStream to write to the output file. We read each line from the input file using the readLine() method of BufferedReader. For each line, we write it to the output file followed by a line separator "\n". This ensures that each line in the output file will end with a LF character, which is the standard end of line character used by Linux. Finally, we close the readers and the output stream to free up resources.

Note: This code assumes that the input file and output file are in the same directory as the Java program. If they are not, you will need to provide the full path to the files.
